ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
TELEVISION IN SINGAPORE
(Government Policy on Introduction)


    Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary whether the Government is considering the introduction of television in Singapore next year, and if he

Column: 1199

will make a statement on the policy of the Government towards the introduction of television in Singapore.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, the Committee which was appointed to examine this matter recommended in its report, which was tabled as Command Paper No. 20 of 1957, that television should be run in conjunction with our broadcasting. The Government agreed with this recommendation and, therefore, deferred consideration until the future of Radio Malaya had been settled through the negotiations which have been taking place with the Federation Government this year.

    Although the exact terms of the financial settlement consequent on the operation of two separate Broadcasting Departments from the beginning of next year have not yet been finally settled with the Federation Government, it is clear that there will be no reconsideration of the decision to break up the Pan-Malayan department, and the Singapore Government is therefore free to make its own plans for the future. As already announced, plans are being put in hand for a commercial service.

    Television, however, as indicated in the report of the Committee, would entail a very considerable initial outlay of Government funds, whether it is operated by the Department of Broadcasting or, as recommended in the report, by a public corporation. In the present financial stringency, the Government does not consider that the provision of these funds would be justified nor would it be proper to commit the incoming Government to such expenditure.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Government prepared to give it to a commercial enterprise if it is too much of a financial burden to the present Government?

    Mr David: Sir, in the report to which I referred, the Committee advised against putting this medium of publicity and information in the hands of private interests. This raises a matter of

Column: 1200

major policy on which this Government does not think it would be right to commit the incoming Government.

APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [3rd December, 1958], "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Question again proposed.

10.07 a.m.

    Mr J. M. Mason (Nominated): I rise with a plea for sanity. On 3rd December, the Financial Secretary informed this House at the commencement of his speech that 1958 has not been a particularly easy year. Most businessmen will have described 1958 in considerably stronger and more derogatory terms. The Financial Secretary went on to inform the House that the recession in trade in the U.S.A. was being felt in Singapore in the spring of 1958 and to use his own words, "By May,, money became tighter. Trade drifted into the doldrums" - a true enough picture. And today there is little real promise of any improvement.

    Singapore business is still on the sick list, and it is only after a fairly long period of convalescence can it be expected to improve. What medicine has the Hon, the Financial Secretary prescribed for the patient that he so clearly diagnosed as sick? Nothing less than a steep rise in company tax of 10 per cent - a medicine which will undoubtedly send the patient back to his sick bed, if not into the morgue! However, Sir,

Column: 1202

we must assume that Government have had to agree to this rather extraordinary measure in order to assist our friends north of the Causeway, who, unlike Singapore, are faced with a very large deficit - surely a noble gesture on our part. Particularly when one realises that had the Company tax in Singapore remained at 30 per cent and the Federation Company tax been increased to 40 per cent, we would have seen an immediate reversal of that flow of industries which have been leaving Singapore for the Federation. How sad the Minister for Commerce and Industry must be to see such an opportunity wasted. Nevertheless, Sir, the proposed action is in accordance with the policy of all Parties in this House, namely, that of co-operation with the Federation, and no doubt it will meet with this House's approval.

    At this stage of the proceedings, most hon. Members no doubt expected that, apart from some minor juggling with tariff duties, the Financial Secretary would resume his seat. Not at all. The Financial Secretary went on to inform the House that although the Federation Government cannot see its way to take similar action, this House is to be asked to approve a rise in the rate of income tax on personal incomes - a proposal surely quite contrary to the agreed policy of co-operation with the Federation Government. With your permission, Sir, I will quote the Financial Secretary's own words:

    "Singapore has no satisfactory future unless she is associated in the closest possible way fiscally, financially and economically with the Federation."

How then does he reconcile his suggestion that Singapore should take independent action? No doubt in his reply the Financial Secretary will assure hon. Members that he is confident that the Federation will follow our action in due course. How often, Sir, have such prophets been discredited? If the Federation Government find that, by having a lower personal income tax - however small the difference may be - they can attract business and businessmen, then

Column: 1203

why should they throw away such an advantage? Why then, when Singapore is struggling, does the Financial Secretary seek to handicap us out of the race?

    I deeply sympathise with the Minister for Commerce and Industry who, with his Pioneer Industries Bill, Control of Manufacture Bill, and other Bills, is doing all he can to assist industry in this Colony, and now, if this motion goes through, will see yet further reasons for businessmen to prefer the Federation to this Island.

    In the course of this debate, hon. Members may be informed that the difference is so small that it will not make any difference, that it will not be sufficient inducement for industry to move to the Federation. That, Sir, is not the point. The principle of a Pan-Malayan fiscal policy is at stake. There is an old proverb, "Great oaks from little acorns grow", and if this House approves this dangerous motion, we may well in the future find that a precedent has been established and that personal income tax in Singapore is always higher than that in the Federation; that is until such time as all business has moved from Singapore to the Federation.

    In the beginning, I referred to an understatement by the Hon, the Financial Secretary regarding 1958, but surely, Sir, he must claim the privilege of the greatest understatement of 1958 when he blandly informed this House that different rates of tax on individual incomes being used in the two territories will not cause any administrative inconvenience or difficulty. I can only think that he meant that it would not cause him any inconvenience personally. I do not for one moment imagine that those officers who are charged with the collection of income tax will endorse his opinion. There are many people whose incomes are unaffected, whether they live and reside in the Federation or in Singapore. Surely then those people will elect to reside in the Federation. It could even be that this, if I may say, ludicrous suggestion might result in loss of collection of income tax in Singapore, instead of earning the paltry $5 million which seem to be

Column: 1204

worrying the Financial Secretary so much. Furthermore, differences in rates of income tax in countries so adjacent as the Federation and Singapore must lead to further evasions of payment of income tax. No administrative difficulties? Nonsense!

    I do not know, of course, what line the P.A.P. will take on this matter. If their leader shows his usual honesty in these matters, he will undoubtedly attack this motion. At the last sitting of this House, the hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar stated that the Federation sets the pace. He will, therefore, surely maul the suggestion that on this occasion we should set the pace. If he does not, I can only assume that he is so confident and so certain that this motion is dangerous, so ill-advised and so down-right silly that it will be worth thousands of votes to his Party next May.

    I know it is difficult, almost impossible, for Government supporters to vote against the Party line. But I would like to remind Members, particularly those who have recently crossed the Floor, of the Financial Secretary's personal opinion. In his speech, these are his very words:

    "In my humble opinion, while an integrated Pan-Malayan economy would be to the incalculable advantage of both territories, Singapore has no satisfactory future unless she is associated in the closest possible way fiscally, financially and economically with the Federation. All possible efforts must be directed over the next two or three years to achieving this association."

    Sir, that is practically an invitation to vote against his own proposal.

    Sir, I am Malayan-born. I have worked all my working life in this country. This is the last speech I shall make in this Assembly. I have no axe to grind All I say to the Financial Secretary is: let him practise what he preaches.

10.22 a.m.

    Mr A. R. Lazarous (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Financial Secretary has in his Budget speech not only referred to the 1959 Estimates, but has also reviewed the Estimates for 1957 and 1958.

    One of the events for which this Government was responsible was the

Column: 1205

Malayanisation Scheme. Sir, the people of Singapore were in favour of this Scheme because they thought that, by this Malayanisation Scheme, quite a good amount of the money that has been paid to the expatriate officers could be saved; and secondly, the local officers who are promoted to fill those vacancies would be able to work for a lesser pay, and, as a result, Government would be able to save quite a large sum of money. But now, this present Government has let down the people of Singapore. They have not only given an enormous amount of money as Malayanisation allowances to the expatriate officers, but they have also allowed the local senior officers who are filling these posts to draw the same amount of pay and allowances as was drawn by expatriate officers.

    Sir, in this Budget, the personal emoluments alone come to about $115 million, i.e. 40 per cent of the entire Budget. I shall quote an example of how the Singapore Government, by this Malayanisation Scheme, has wasted a big sum of money. Sir, I am taking my example from the Public Works Department. An engineer who is in a very junior grade, say, for example, draws $800 a month. The senior officer, who was supposed to draw, say, $3,000 a month, by taking advantage of the Malayanisation Scheme, retires. The next man gets in; he retires. And then another man gets in. But all these men who are getting to the top are receiving the same amount of pay. If there is an engineer in a junior post who wants to retire, let him retire when he is in the junior capacity. By taking advantage of this senior capacity allowance, the senior officer retires, and when he does so, the junior man takes his place and receives the same allowance and the same pay. If a junior officer retires when he is drawing $800 or $1,000 a month, he is supposed to get $30,000 under the Malayanisation Scheme; but when he moves up to a senior position,

Column: 1206

he is not only drawing $3,000 and allowances but is also getting the benefit of the Malayanisation Scheme by which he will be able to draw about $100,000.

    Sir, when I examine very closely the implications of this Malayanisation Scheme, I personally cannot but feel that it was merely a conspiracy between certain local senior officers and expatriate officers conveniently to collect big sums of money at the cost of the Singapore taxpayers.

    Sir, here is a good case to review the salary scale of senior Government officers. With this end in view, I would ask this Government to set up a Salary Commission to review the salaries of the senior officers who are drawing, say, $500 and above. Pruning must start from the top and not at the bottom, which the Government usually does.

    I know that recently there was a scheme to reduce the salaries of the lower-paid staff - the Normal trained teachers, nurses and so on.

    In this connection, I wish to express the hope when the Yang di-Pertuan Negara replaces the Governor, it will not cost the same amount of money which goes to meet the expense to maintain the establishment of the Governor. Pomp and ceremony must give way to the needs of the people and Singapore cannot afford to imitate the colonial system and the ancient monarchies.

    I would suggest that when the present Governor vacates his residence, this palatial building could be used as a museum or as an art gallery or converted to some educational or aesthetic activity.

    Lastly, I would like to congratulate this Government on introducing relief work for the unemployed. Quite a lot of people in Singapore are without jobs. But the $1.5 million provided is quite inadequate. I would request Government to make provision for at least $2 million or $3 million from the money taken from the highly-paid senior officers in Government service.

Column: 1207



10.28 a.m.

    Mr Seah Peng Chuan (Kampong Kapor): Mr Speaker, Sir, in my opinion, the Budget for 1959 was drafted by some very clever men with a view to pulling wool over the eyes of the public. The Budget will not, in fact, improve the standard of living of the man-in-the-street. It provides nothing new in the form of improving the standard of living of the people. What the Government is asking from them is to pay more income tax, pay more for cigarettes and unemployment. As a direct result, Government is forced to increase company tax to meet the Budget.

    Sir, when the Government increases company tax to bring it at par with the Federation, I wonder whether this will affect the future industrialisation of this country. We are facing unemployment, and need more and more industries to absorb the unemployed. It is the duty of the Government to give all possible assistance to industry, so that people may be encouraged to invest more in Singapore. There will then be more employment for our youths.

    In fact, the Government has increased the taxes just to please the Federation. I do not know the reason why such a heavy tax was imposed on companies. I want this House to know that this Bill has a far-reaching effect on the economy and social standing of this country. Let me ask the Government one question. Has the Federation at any time shown a willingness to co-operate with us, unless their interests are involved? I am sure all will agree with me that there must be mutual understanding and co-operation in all undertakings.

    Sir, coming to the Budget now, let me recall a statement made by the Hon, the Financial Secretary when he said that the revenue for the year 1959 will be a record one in post-war years; but he did not say a word about the expenditure which beats all previous records. In other words, we will have a record revenue but with greater expenditure than in previous years. Government has no plan for any capital expenditure. We have to increase income tax and duty on cigarettes.

Column: 1208



    Another feature of the Budget is that money is being provided for all Ministries, although many of them will have to undergo clerical changes after the general elections next year. I am at a loss to understand as to what will happen to the surplus money voted for these Ministries when they undergo changes. We may accumulate this as a gift to the British Government, which is what the Progressive Party did in 1950!

    Sir, this is a standstill Budget and, as such, I do not wish to go into detail. However, I would like to point out that this Budget is drawn up with a view to collecting the maximum from the rate-payers and to providing them with little amenities, which is contrary to democratic principles. May I remind hon. Members of the House that they have been elected by the people to look after their interests and not to repress them in the name of democracy or socialism? Sir, we have to carry out the mandate of the people and we have to answer them very shortly when we stand on the public platform again.

    Sir, with regard to unemployment, I would like to point this out to the Minister for Labour. In page 1 of the Strait's' Times of Thursday, 11th December, 1958, the speech of the Minister of Commerce and Industry, Federation - not Singapore - was reported.

    "He disclosed that more than 40 new factories will begin operations in Malaya next year."

This shows how much the Federation Government is doing for the welfare of the people. Further to that, Sir, he said:

    "Closure of even one factory will throw hundreds of people out of work."

He expressed concern over the families of these hundreds of people by saying:

    "This means that thousands of human beings will suffer because their families will also be affected."

    That means that he has at heart the interest not only of the workers who will be unemployed but also their families. That is very clever of the Minister of Commerce and Industry of the Federation.

Column: 1209



    On the question of the ban on textiles, Sir, which was imposed by the Federation with the co-operation of our Minister for Commerce and Industry, the Minister of Commerce and Industry, Federation, said:

    "We appreciate this point of view as we realise that Singapore lives by trade and without it she dies."

That means we are depending on trade. If we have no trade, it means we are finished and the only thing that we can get is a lot of grass all over Singapore. Sir, the Minister said on 4th December that at the end of the three-month period, he hoped to impose anti-dumping legislation so that it would then be possible for Singapore to receive her unrestricted import of textiles, and other goods for that matter, if she so desires. Sir, now is the time for the Hon. the Minister for Commerce and Industry to consider lifting this ban so that every one of us can enjoy this Christmas and the approaching Chinese New Year with cheaper goods.

10.37 a.m.

    Mr Tan Siak Kew (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, when introducing increases in tax, the Hon, the Financial Secretary said this:

    "Nothing has been done to upset the economy of Singapore. The incidence of taxation has been in strict proportion to capacity to pay and no hardship has been caused to anyone ... It [the Government] has merely done what was required to make income meet expenditure."

Sir, I find it extremely difficult to agree with his remarks. It must be recognised that as far as income tax is concerned, the rate is already very high, especially when compared with laces like Hongkong which, after all, in functional activity, is similar to that of Singapore. The individual maximum rate at one time was the same as the company rate. It has only been increased last year from 30 per cent to 40 per cent, and now it is proposed to increase it to 50 per cent. We see, on the one hand, that the Government is trying to attract investments in industry by introducing measures such as the

Column: 1210

Pioneer Industries (Relief from Income Tax) Bill and the Industrial Expansion (Relief from Income Tax) Bill - not that we believe anything big will come out of it - but nevertheless it is the right thing to do and even the Hon. the Financial Secretary is hoping for a good atmosphere to raise loans because increasing development cannot be entirely financed out of revenue or reserves hereafter; but almost in the same breath, it seems to nullify its own aims and hopes by proposing this crushing increase in income tax. Industry is a long-term venture. The Hon. the Minister for Commerce and Industry had often deprecated that people here were only interested in short-term turnovers and was always urging people to look ahead. Even if there are bold people who could be attracted by the Government's measures of tax relief to invest in industries, none could be so optimistic as to expect any worthwhile return during the first five years allowed for relief; but when they look beyond these five years to find not only a high rate of tax but a frame of mind on the part of those in authority that rigidly justifies this heavy incidence with such lighthearted remarks that the Government has merely done what is required to make income meet expenditure, then even those bold people will surely have no need to think twice before they discover that there is, in fact, no attraction at all.

    Sir, we are not without competition. Every country in this region, not excluding Australia which the Hon. the Minister for Commerce and Industry has included in his list of capital exporting countries - all these countries are craving for investments, and the attractions in many of these places are better than ours. How can the Government expect any investors to come forward when they are even now taking steps to deter them? Individual taxpayers, and this category includes shopkeepers both proprietary and in partnership, need as much as companies to have sufficient reserves from earnings in order to expand or even to maintain their business, because they have to continue to extend credits and other capital formation if they are to

Column: 1211

handle the same volume of business from year to year. If they are taxed too high, they are unable to do so and the potential from which we derive this tax is gradually weakened. Even with a business which can maintain its profits, one effect of this increase will be to deprive or to decrease whatever the employee gets as bonus, or as any other form of reward at the close of the year, and business generally will not be able to pay the same dividends. Sir, I personally know of two big businesses which have been trying to overcome the bad times they were encountering by a reorganisation. The announcement of this increase has decided them to fold up altogether and, of course, a lot of people are out of work.

    Now this is a clear indication that a heavy tax kills enterprise. Who would be willing to risk - and all enterprises are risks - when he realises that on a 50/50 chance if he loses, he loses a whole dollar of his capital, and when he makes, he is only allowed to retain 50 cents? There are, of course, those who would, because they have to do something, but then there is this added incentive for them to evade. The estimate for collection of income tax for 1959 shows a decrease of $10 million which Government fully knows is due to reduced earnings of some companies during the last 12 months, and it shows that reduced earnings must now be punished with a higher rate. The most curious thing about this is why individual tax which had only been increased last year by 10 per cent should again be increased by another 10 per cent this year. In spite of the Government's protestations that we should agree with the Federation in all things, including monetary, fiscal and economic policies, why should we find it necessary to disagree with the Federation in this respect of tax policy? Is it merely on the grounds that it will not cause any administrative inconvenience and difficulties? My hon, friend here has been more eloquent than I in this respect, but I think the civil servant, for one, will wish that he were in the Federation, and no doubt others too.

    The deficit budgetted for - $21 million - represents only an item of development;

Column: 1212

$20 million having to be transferred from revenue to Development Fund. The Hon, the Financial Secretary has said that future increasing development cannot be totally financed from revenue and must be financed largely from loans. There are, of course, mounting expenditures on the social services, particularly education, which it is estimated will increase by $10 million every year; and there are the personal emoluments which is $10 million over 1958. Can these be financed by increasing the rate of income tax from year to year? For instance, the increase of 10 per cent in company tax yields $10 million which approximates the increase of $10 million for education every year. Next year we raise another 10 per cent in company tax. This will be eaten up by education alone and so on until we tax the companies 100 per cent. What then? Will it catch up with the ever- increasing expenditure? It is clear that the pattern of taxation to which the population has been accustomed has been exhausted. If the goose is not to be further weakened, ways must be found to curb this increasing expenditure and new avenues of revenue must be sought. Why always pick on income tax? I am wondering what is wrong with the Social Welfare lottery and the tax on bookmakers which has so often been mooted. These will surely bring in at least $10 million with no hardship to anyone. If there are any objections, whether on moral grounds or on whatever grounds, then what is being done, and is it possible to eliminate these activities?

    To tax the businessmen seems to be the easiest way out for Government, because the businessmen's voice is feeble. But care must be taken to see that this section must not be unduly weakened, because it is this section which will at all times provide for our upkeep.

    The Hon. the Financial Secretary has said that "the new Government will be considerably exercised to find means of taxation which will not weigh penally on any particular section of

Column: 1213

the community or business interests in Singapore, which will not harm the economy . . ." Strangely enough, I suggest it is doing just that.

10.52 a.m.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, after hearing the warning by the hon. Mr Mason that those who have crossed the Floor should consider very carefully before supporting this motion, I feel that I must in duty bound give my personal opinion of what I think of the Budget.

    Unlike previous Budgets which had so many items for Members to pick on, this year's Budget has one very important item to which several Members before me have referred, and that is the increase of income tax.
